div1.p: THE Amorous Widow: OR, THE WANTON WIFE. A COMEDY. As it is Perform'd by Her MAJESTY'S Servants.
Written by the late Famous Mr. THOMAS BETTERTON.
Now first Printed from the Original Copy.

list.label: SIR Peter Pride. A great Boaster of his Honour, his Valour, what a noble Family he is deriv'd from, and of their mighty Courage.
Cuningham. A Gentleman in love with Philadelphia, and is much courted by the Widow.
Lovemore. His Friend, in love with Mr. Brittle's Wife, and endeavours to have an Intrigue with her; but the Widow courts him too.
Barnaby Brittle. An old Citizen that keeps a Glassshop, marry'd to Sir Peter Pride's Daughter.
Jeffrey. Servant to Cuningham, in love with Prudence.
Clodpole. A simple Country Fellow that Lovemore employs in sending Letters to Mrs. Brittle.
Merryman. A Falconer to Cuningham, who takes upon him to represent the Viscount Sans-Terre, that is to marry the Widow.
Lady Laycock. An amorous old Widow, that courts every one she can for Marriage, sancying her self so engaging, that all that see her must love her.
Lady Pride. Wife to Sir Peter, a formal old Lady that boasts much of her Gentility, and of her great Name and Family.
Mrs. Brittle. Their Daughter, Wife to Barnaby Brittle; a Cunning, Intrieguing Coquet, that always over-reaches her Husband.
Philadelphia. Niece to the Widow, in love with Cuningham.
Prudence. Maid to the Widow.
Damaris. Maid to Mrs. Brittle, that assists her in her Intriegues.

body.head: THE Amorous Widow: OR, THE WANTON WIFE.

div2.head: SCENE a Room.
div2.stage: Enter Philadelphia with a Letter, follow'd by Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I Should believe Mr. Cuningham very constant, if I had Faith enough to credit this Letter, Jeffry. What Complaints are here? But 'tis the Stile, that all young Lovers write.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, believe me; you know I am a Man of Integrity: I cannot dissemble. Let him write what he pleases, If he did not love you, do you think I'd tell you so?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: When he has Opportunity, I must confess, he says kind things to me.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Take my Word, Madam, my Master is not like other Men—Unless he loves a Lady, and loves her passionately too, he never troubles himself to compliment her much.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Never? Yes, Jeffry; sometimes, you know, he compliments my Aunt.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: That's a convincing Proof of his Love to you; you cannot think him reduc'd to the Necessity of making Love to an antiquated Piece, with design to know her otherwise, than to obtain the Happiness of seeing you? But I shall tell him, Madam—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Tell him I have receiv'd and read his Letter.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Is that all, Madam?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: All! Yes. Are you not content with that?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Any indifferent Person, that had Hands, and could but read, would have done, as much, as that.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well; Tell him then, in time perhaps I may—

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: My Master, Madam, can't endure to depend on a perhaps.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Quick, quick, up to your Chamber, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What's the Matter? Is my Aunt coming hither?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: She's at your Heels. Go up the Back-Stairs quickly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Farewel, Jeffry; Commend me to thy Master. Exit Phil.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: For what, I beseech you? Is not my Master bewitc'd, to court a Lady a whole Year, and she hardly tell him she loves him yet?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Alas! She's but a Novice. Let me alone with her; I'll order the Business so, that if thy Master be discreet and passionate enough in his Expressions, he wins her Heart I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: He can say nothing to her, but that damn'd Aunt of hers is harkning to't still. What Pleasure can she find in Love at Fifty?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Fie, Jeffry, you must say Five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I wonder any Woman can have the Impudence to live, and trouble Mankind after that Age.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: There never was a Woman so old, but she retain'd a good Opinion of her self.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Then she dresses her self so fantastically, that all may see she strives to appear Young in defiance of Nature. She is more gawdy in that she calls Half-Mourning, than a young Bride is on her Wedding-Night. The Devil's in her if she believes any one can love her: 'Tis jeering her, but to be commonly civil to her.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A little Flattery fires her. She believes all, that is said to her: And he that does not make love to her, and compliment her, shall not be twice admitted to her House.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: O reverend Beauty! on my Conscience, if I would grease her Chops with a few Compliments, she'd mump and smile upon me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: When shall my Master have an Opportunity to speak freely to Philadelphia?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Mr. Lovemore is thy Master's Friend, and is better belov'd here, than he imagines You must persuade him to amuse the Aunt, that Mr. Cuningham may have Convenience to court the Niece.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Mr. Lovemore's tir'd with playing that part so often; he is cloy'd with the Aunt, and swears he'll have no more of her.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I'm sure her Niece and I endure much more. Tell him, 'twill be Charity in him to relieve us.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: 'Twill be hard to persuade him to it.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: This old Lady of mine has languish'd for a young Husband ever since Sir Oliver Laycock dy'd: She cares not what Estate he has, or what Religion he's of, so he be but young and lusty. Where is the great Viscount Sans Terre, thy Master told her of? Methinks he's long a coming.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Some cross unlucky Business hinders him.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: She has lately receiv'd some Letters, that have given a full Account of him.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: So much the worse. What is it?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: They say his Fortune is not very much, but he is greatly born, and very pleasant; and that he is so great a Lover of Musick, he has not a Servant but can Sing or Dance, or Play upon some Instrument. You may know when he's come by the Noise; the Fiddlers will welcome him to Town; for all from Westminster to Wapping pay him Homage.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Wou'd he were but marry'd to her, Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Whether he marries her or not, is not our Business, Jeffry. Let him but fool with us till thy Master has gain'd her Niece, and then our Work is done.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Well, we have had enough of thy old Lady Laycock. Let us now talk of our own Affairs; speak, dost thou love me, Prudence?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A pleasant Question! Do you doubt it now?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: If you would have me credit you, swear it.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Sure you are jealous Jeffry?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: You're somewhat near the Matter. I know your Humour well enough; you love a bold audacious Fellow, that will say any thing, and such a one we have come to Town, one Merryman our Falconer; I fear you'll like him better than you do me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh Fool! why should you think so?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I have some Honour in me; but he's a Fellow that has eaten Shame, and drank after it. He is more impudent than a Court Page, and will take no Denial.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, here's my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What Business has Jeffry with you?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: His Master sent him to know, whether he might have leave to wait upon your Ladyship this Morning.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes; Tell him, I expect him.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: He durst not come, because Mr. Lovemore's with him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go tell 'em, if they please to come, they shall be welcome both.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I shall, Madam. (Exit Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: You see what Power your Beauty has. Neither can live a Moment without seeing you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, they have other Business with me, Prudence; they came from Paris lately, and brought me a Letter from my Brother; and I believe they come for my Answer now.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But does not one of 'em love you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have some Reason to believe he does; Mr. Lovemore has spar'd no Pains to persuade me to quit my Widow-hood.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I have been told, Madam, that Widow-hood is a Gift, Heaven seldom bestows but on its Favourites; you are rich, and know how troublesome Marriage is. For my part, I believe the fairest Hair, the beautiful'st Curls do not become your Fore-head so well as Bando did; but every one, Madam, knows their own Necessities.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I confess, Widow-hood has its Conveniencies; but if Marriage be a Trouble to some, 'tis a Pleasure to others, Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: You had the Experience of it thirty Years, how did you like it, Madam? They say, Sir Oliver Laycock lov'd your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For all that he was jealous; and, what's worse, was Old.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Very well; therefore you resolve to have a young One now, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You cannot blame me for that? Can you, Prudence?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh no, 'tis well known Youth is comfortable. But, methinks, you should take one a little nearer your own Age, Madam. A very young Man may be too treacherous for you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, is my Age so visible?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No, Madam; with a little Help of Art you have some Remains of Beauty still. You have something about your Eyes as pleasant now, as others have at Twenty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis a very malicious World we live in, Prudence; they are so apt to censure, and speak of any single Woman, that one ought to marry to avoid that Scandal.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Some that are young are forc'd to marry, to avoid Detraction; others wou'd rather all that's Ill should be said of them, than to have no Notice taken of 'em. I knew a young Lady that pin'd to a Consumption, because she liv'd three Years about the Court, and never had the Honour to be lampoon'd. The Truth is, none that are Beautiful and Young can avoid Envy, but few are so malicious, to speak against the Old.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There is no Age exempt from Scandal, Prudence. When we are Young, they say we sell our selves; when Old, we are forc'd to hire, to buy our Lovers.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: You know what they say, Madam, of the old Marchioness, your Friend, that was so admir'd, so courted in her Youth; who, when she found she was forsook by all, was forc'd to hire a Player by the Quarter: How soon rhe poor Fellow was tir'd too! How like a Sheep-biter he look'd after the first two Months!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This London is a very wicked Place, 'tis impossible to live without Scandal here.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I'm afraid they'll say as much of you, Madam, if you bargain for a Husband. To covet one, that is both Young and Rich, is too much in Conscience, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Thou know'st, Prudence, Wealth is not the thing I seek.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Then, Madam, the Business is done; the Viscount Sans-Terre shall be your Husband, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah Prudence! if he were but as handsome as—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ah Madam, that's too much.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why may not I wish for it?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Consider his Quality, Madam, and 'bate him something for that. One thing I must advise you; be not too prodigal of your Gold at first; to be liberal sometimes will be convenient, and make him kinder to you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For all this, I should think my self very happy, if I were certain of Mr. Cuningham or Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A little Jealousy will inflame 'em. They'll be more pressing when the Viscount comes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But yet methinks, Cuningham and my Neice—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: What, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Are always whispering.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: He only compliments her, Madam. She's too young to make Love seriously.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With your Favour, there's no trusting to that. To my Knowledge, there are those younger, than she, that understand what Love is but too well.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: That's true, Madam; but Philadelphia is so innocent, that no Man can make Love to her, but to divert himself. Here she is, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What does she come for? I'll send her packing quickly.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Consider what you do, Madam. How can Mr. Lovemore entertain your Ladyship, unless his Friend may divert himself the while with rallying with your Niece.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For all that I could wish—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Pray trouble not your self. Trust me, I'll watch her, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Will your Ladyship go to Eaton's? The Coach is at the Door.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, I'll not go yet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If you stay long, Madam, the best Poynt will be sold before you come.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No matter. Ha! what ails the Girl! How strangely she looks! Her Eyes are hardly open yet!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then her Head's dress'd awry. How it disguises her! Lord! how frightfully it looks!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Truly, Aunt, 'tis dress'd just as the Fashion is.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Fetch her Hood, Prudence; I'll have her put it on till it be mended.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I dress'd it to please no body but my self, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll have you dress your self now to please me: Come, put it on.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: My Lady's in the Right. Never was any thing more ridiculous. Here, put on the Hood, I am sure this is much handsomer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why don't you put it on?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I can't endure it, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do, I say.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: So; Now it is as it should be; all modest Maids should be dress'd so: But here's Mr. Cuningham and Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam; you see how we love your Company, by giving you this Trouble in a Morning.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Tis a Happiness we are much envy'd for.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are welcome, Gentlemen. Pray command this House as freely as your own.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why does this Lady hide her Face? Pray, Madam, let us see you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Forbear, Sir, I beseech you: She has had the Tooth-Ach lately. If she takes off her Hood, she'll catch cold, and bring the Pain again.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I thank your Ladyship for your Care of me. But the Pain has been gone so long, I don't fear it now.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay then, we must have it off.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What say you, Madam, Shall I pull it off?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, Impertinence; I see you have a Mind to shew your self.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: 'Tis the Nature of all young Girls to do what they are forbidden.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I come not to trouble your Ladyship for your Letter to my Lawyer; your countenancing my Business will be of great Advantage to me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This, Sir, is what my Brother commands me: You shall see I take delight to serve his Friends.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, You promis'd me that Honourable Title.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you pretend to it?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, more, than any one.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have not much Beauty to boast of; but Virtue, Sir, makes some amends for the Defects of the other.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Defects? (Cuningham Courts Philadelphia. Pray, Madam, wrong not your self so much.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There are few but know a little their own Value: And tho a Woman be not fam'd for a great Beauty, yet if she be agreeable, there are those, will like her well enough.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You have that in Perfection, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: In that, Sir, I know you do not flater.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Then, Madam, you like my Choice of this Suit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Extremely well: Was it your own Fancy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I am not asham'd to own it, since you ask it, Madam.

div2.stage: [They counterfeit to be talking about Fashions, whilst seemingly Lovemore Courts the Aunt.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I'll listen to 'em—
He talks to her of nothing but new Fashions. [To the Widow. You may, Madam, venture to discourse without disturbance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, tell me freely; how old do you think I am?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, if you were not a Widow, I should think you a Girl scarce Twenty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now, Sir, you flater me: You might have said Thirty. I do not love to disguise my Age.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How! Thirty, Madam! and look so youthful: I'll not believe it, 'tis impossible!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You do not know what Misery I endur'd whilst my old Husband liv'd. The Griefs I had upon me would have distracted another Woman. Alas! Sir, 'tis not Age but Sorrow has broke me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It makes me sad to hear you tell it, Madam, and vexes me to think, an old Man should enjoy such Happiness.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You do not know how many Tears I have shed.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Tis some Comfort, Madam, to remember he did not live long with you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, Fifteen Years.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Yes, and Fifteen to that. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Having been so unfortunate in a Husband, you may believe I have but little Encouragement to venture, Sir, again. For I am very happy now I am alone.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You do wisely, Madam; for she deserves not to be pity'd, that rashly runs into the same Misfortune; and therefore you have, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I have not forsworn Marrying yet.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, where do you use to walk in the Evening? Into St. James's Park?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not very often, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Or into the Mulberry Garden?
Is not the Wilderness very pleasant?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If I like my Company, Sir, I never mislike the Place.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Have you seen the new Paradise, Madam? 'Tis much superiour to the former.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have heard as much: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Let me have the Honour to wait upon you thither presently.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Not yet, Sir; After Dinner, if you please. But tell me, Sir, do you think me such an Enemy to Marriage, that were I sure a young Gentleman lov'd
me, and lov'd me truly, I would be so uncivil to refuse him?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: When I consider what you endur'd in Sir Oliver Laycock's time, I think you ought to do it, Madam; and that Man's unjust, that urges you to break your Resolution.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray do not mistake me, Sir; I have made no such Resolution yet.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, since you are displeas'd at what I said, we'll change the Discourse. Pray, Madam, do you think the young Lord Lucky has that Interest at Court, that Fame reports he has?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, this is a strange wild Answer to my Question. Let me tell you, Sir, if I have any Merit, Wealth or Beauty, there's one in the World deserves 'em all.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Good! How she teazes him! (Aside.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But has that one no Fault, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You know him very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I know him, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, you, Sir. 'Tis your self.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! What will become of me now?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The Marchioness is come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Troublesome Creature. Go one of you and entertain her quickly.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Which of us, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go you, Philadelphia, and keep her Company till I come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I shall, Madam. (Exit Phil.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what is this Marchioness?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir! a most eternal Talker: Her Tongue goes like the Larum of a Clock, as fast, and to the
same Tune still. She's almost Sixty, and yet pretends to Beauty, and loves Courtship most unreasonably. Say but a kind thing to her, and you win her Heart. The Truth is, she has not much Reputation; but the Respect I give her is to her Quality and to her Person. But she's an Original in her kind, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh blind, blind Creature! she draws her own Picture, and laughs at it.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Sure, Madam, her Conversation must be very pleasant?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: She has been much courted in her Youth; but 'twould make one die to hear her boast of her Lovers now. How this Knight sighs, and that Lord dies for her; when all the while I know what Necessity the poor Creature is reduc'd to. I would have brought her hither, but I know we never should have been rid of her. Excuse me a Moment, I'll send her away, and return presently. Your Servant, Gentlemen, Exit Lady.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: How now, Friend—What's the Matter? Why dost look so sullenly?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I play the Ass here any longer! No; if I do, may I turn Pudding to a Rope-Dancer, and shew Tricks next Bartholomew Fair.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Nay, but Friend, Dear Friend—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Tell not me of Friendship. What Man would endure to be so plagued as I have been. I have parry'd with my best Skill the dangerous Thrusts that ever were made at me. To tug at an Oar, or dig in a Mine in Peru, is Recreation to it. But the first time to offer Marriage to me! I sweat to think on it. It made me tremble twice, for fear she should have forc'd my Neck into her muddy Noose of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: We have no other way to blind her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Tis all one to me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: If thou lov'st my Life, Friend, do not forsake me now.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray live, if you please, and give me leave to do so too. Should I again be left alone with her, the best I can hope for is Distraction.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: How do you like the Niece?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She's all Perfection.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: How do you thrive? Do you find her kind, Mr. Cuningham?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She has promis'd me a Meeting this Afternoon, if thou canst but remove the Aunt from us.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I'll try what I can do, but Mr. Lovemore is the only Man in her Favour.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Dear Friend, try but this one.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd, drawn, and quarter'd for a Traitor first, and have my Limbs hung up for the Birds to feed upon. No, no, I have my Belly full, I thank you, and some to spare.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But now I think on't, where's this Viscount all this while? His Arrival wou'd be of great use in this Affair.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prudence advises well: Methinks he's long a coming.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Why, you must know, there is one Merryman just come up out of the Country-He is my Falconer upon occasion, the Fellow is bold, and very apt, and has not been seen much in Town. What think you of him to act awhile, till some more lucky Occasion present it self?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Tis a lucky Thought, and may be of use. Where is he?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: In the Pantry, a ramming down a Wedge of Roast-Beef to keep out the Town Air, and making Sport with a simple Country Fellow he has brought out of the Country with him to see the Town; one Clodpole, he calls him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Twould not be amiss to examine him, and instruct him how to behave himself, before he is too much known.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: No body of the Family has seen him▪ yet, but the Butler; and he, I know, will be secret.
I'll step and call him to you, Sir, if you please?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Do so. (Exit Jeff.
In the mean time, Prudence, there's something to buy thee a Pair of Gloves. (Gives her Money.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! how long have I deserved this? Please to command me any thing within my Power, and conclude it done.

div2.stage: Enter Jeffrey with Merryman dress'd like a Falconer.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Sir, I found him just passing by the Door, and have told him part of the Business.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, Friend, dost think thou can'st act the Part of a Viscount for a little while?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: What sort of a Lord is he to be?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh! An Amorous Resolute sort of a Person, that's much given to love Musick. You shall have all things that's sitting for a Man of such Quality.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Well, Sir, let me be once set out with a good Equipage, and leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come with us, Friend, and we'll instruct thee fully in thy Part.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Well, give me but my Cue of Entrance, and let me alone to act my Part.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Let's about it then. (Exit Lovemore, Cuningham and Merryman.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Prudence—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: What's your Will?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: One Kiss.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: 'Pshaw! Is that all? (He kisses her.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: All! I say no more, but—
Ah Prudence, Prudence!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: What damnable whining Tone hast thou got, ha?

sp.speaker: Jeff
sp.p: I am afraid of this Viscount, Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Away, you Fool; I have other things to trouble my Head withal—Farewel.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Adieu. (Exeunt severally.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: WHy, Madam, are you so unwilling to credit what my constant Passion, so long in vain, has urg'd? Do you not believe I love you? Oh! Did you but know what I endure, when you refuse to hear me, you would in Charity have some Compassion on my wounded Soul.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I dare not hear this Language from you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What are you afraid of, Madam?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: All Men say the same things, Sir, till they have won our easy Hearts to pity and believe you; then straight you slight your Conquest, and leave us to pursue our Ruin.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Be not so cruel to censure all for those Faults, which some few commit; for all, I must confess, do not stand excus'd. But, Madam, you cannot be so great a Stranger to my Love, as not to think it real; or so great an Enemy to your own Worth, to believe it has not Power to enslave a Heart, that's guarded more securely than mine—But no more—Your Aunt—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So Niece, I see your squeamish Stomach can digest all sorts of Diet, tho ne'er so strictly charg'd to the contrary. Mr. Cuningham, What Business have you with her? I wonder you are not asham'd to be always following of her at this rate, and endeavouring to take Advantage of her foolish Youth; for she is but a Girl yet, and not fit for the Conversation of a Man, nay, or indeed to be trusted with her self.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go, go, indeed you are much to blame▪ What will the World judge, think you? Or what Excuse can I make, for suffering such Doings in my House? And you, Huswife! how dare you disobey my Commands? Is this the Respect you pay to me, and to my Quality! I believe, in a little time I must make it my whole Imploy to invite home young Gallants, forsooth, to pleasure you, whilst I, as if I were your Slave, must retire, and wait till you are serv'd first. 'Tis come to a fine pass indeed; but I'll put an End to it all, and keep you always lock'd up in your Chamber, I will so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I told you▪ Sir, what would be the Event of your Projects, but you would not be said nay. I must be an Instrument to make your Passion known, and none so fit to be trusted with such an Affair as I; but henceforward if you can't speak for your self, you may hang or drown, as you pretend, for me, for I'll no more get Anger for you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What does she mean?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What's that you say?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mr. Cuningham here, Madam, is always urging me to tell your Ladyship the Passion he has for you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Saucy Slut!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: As if he could not speak for himself, but must be still plaguing me, and swearing how long, how well, and how tenderly he loves you; then sighs and cries, Oh Philadelphia! Can I live without her? But she, cruel as she is▪ has vow'd to die unmarried.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! What will become of me now?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Then raves worse, than any one in Bedlam, crying, And must I then lose her so? Oh! Death to all my Hopes! I must not, cannot, will not! and a thousand such like things, which I'm resolv'd never to hear again. So, Sir, don't trouble me any more, but e'en speak what you have to say to her your self.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is this true, Mr. Cuningham? I did not think there was a Man living, which cou'd love at that rate, and with such Constancy.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! what shall I say, since all is still in vain! Your Vow, your cruel Vow, has vanquish'd all my Hopes; then where should I seek for Peace, but in my last Retreat, the Grave. Farewell; I cannot bear to stay, for every Look adds new Poisons to my Soul. (Is going.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Stay, Sir—I have made no such Vow. If your Passion—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! forbear. I know your Goodness to be such, that rather, than be the Instrument of what may happen, you would seemingly comply with any thing I can ask. Pardon me, Madam, I have been too much deceiv'd already.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray stay, Sir, do not mistake—

div2.stage: Enter Philadelphia with a Piece of Poynt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, here's the finest Piece of Poynt I ever saw, and the cheapest; pray, Madam, look at it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Saucy Intrusion. How durst you come without being call'd? How often have I told you this, you Minx: Be gone, and leave it in the next Room, till I please to come and look on't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam, the Woman, that brought it is in haste, she bid me tell your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let her go about her Business, if she can't wait, for I'll not come yet. (Exit Philadelphia.
How horribly unlucky was this to disturb me, just as I was going to tell him of my Intentions, and of my Concern for his Passion. (A side.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I believe I am troublesome, Madam. (Is going. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, pray stay, Sir, I have something to say to you, but that young Slut interrupted me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh the Devil!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But as I was going to say, I did indeed resolve not to marry any more; and when you have heard me out, you'll say I had Reason.

You must know, in my Husband Sir Oliver's Days, I had not that Liberty, perhaps, as other Ladies of Quality took; for, to say Truth, my airy Temper and my Youth, at that time, made my Husband grows jealous, tho' without Cause, Heaven knows.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: That I dare swear, if all were of my Mind.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Which made him lead me a very uneasy Life: So that it made me resolve on many things at that time, and one was this, That if ever Sir Oliver should die, I never would marry again; but I don't remember that I swore to it: Or if I had, you have such a way with you, 'twould be very hard to deny you any thing, Mr. Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, Madam!—Your Charity comes now too late: I am past all Hope.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir, say not so! for since you say your Disease is grown to that Extremity, that unless your Love meet Reward—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Talk not of Impossibilities. I know how much you prize your Honour: And since you have vow'd never to marry, I have nothing left to hope for else.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Mr. Cuningham, I would not have my Honour suffer; but what remains beside that I can do, to save you from what may be dangerous, shall not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! Madam! the rarest News—The Viscount Sans Terre, whom you have so long expected, is just arriv'd, and is coming hither with a huge fine Equipage, Fiddles, and other Instruments.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh dear! how I'm surpriz'd! I would not have him see me thus for all the World. Prudence, Ser my Curls right, and alter my Knots: Quickly, don't stand sumbling—
Look if the Paint be sirm.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: 'Tis pretty well, Madam; There's here and there a small Crack, but 'twill not be discern'd at distance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Quickly, good Prudence: Put me a little better in Order. You'll pardon me, Sir: You see what a Fright I'm in.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Pardon, quotha! the Devil take me, if any thing could be more freely granted. (Aside.

div2.stage: Enter the Viscount Sans Terre, with Musick, and a good Equipage; attended by Lovemore and several Gentlemen. The Viscount sings as he enters.

lg.head: A CATCH.
lg.l: Where I heard of the Fame
I had pass'd for an Ass,
Had I stay'd where I was,
And not done a Viscount's Duty.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Oh! are these the Ladies?
By your Favour, Sweet Lady. (Kisses Philadelphia.
A delicate Morsel, by this Hand.
Madam, I see that Fame has justly spoke your Praise. You are indeed the Wonder of all your Sex.
How fair she is!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What does he mean?

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what young Gentlewoman is that, whose matchless Beauty seems to sill the Place with more, than common Brightness? Sure 'tis some Goddess, dropt from Heaven for Men to worship!
Fair Angel, pardon this rude Attempt:
The Honour only of your fair Hand. (Kisses it.
For till I touch it, I cannot think you mortal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! You make me blush.

sp.speaker: Vis.
sp.p: [To Phil.] Pray, Lady, is this pretty young Gentlewoman your Niece?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: [Aside.] This Fellow must be a Fool, or he could ne'er mistake so grosly.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [To Phil.] Now we shall have rare Sport. Sure he's blind to mistake you for your Aunt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: [To Phil.] Pray have a little Patience, Madam, and you'll see the Event.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Lady; I bless those Stars that have directed me to so happy a Choice; therefore few Words are best. If you like me as well as I do like you, e'en send for a Parson— To Phil.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, sure you mistake!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Now—Now it works. [Aside to Phil.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: What say you, Lady? Shall we— [To Phil.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I can hold no longer. [Aside.
Pray, Sir, are not you the Viscount Sans Terre?

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Pretty Creature, I am.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And come with an Intention—

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: To make this Lady, your Aunt, happy in a Husband, if she pleases.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, I am that Lady you speak of; and that is, my Niece Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; Your Niece, quotha!
Why sure you think to put some Trick upon me.
This motherly grave Lady your Niece!
No, No; I thank you, Madam, I am not to be perswaded out of my Reason.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He makes me almost mad. (Aside.
I say again, that I am call'd the Lady Laycock;
And that pert Minx my Niece; who was left in Charge with me till she be of Age.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: 'Sdheart, 'tis impossible! You look Twenty Years younger than that Lady you call your Niece.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! That indeed may well be: A great many do allow, I appear to be something younger than I altogether am.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: How could I be so much mistaken!
Sure, Madam, you but jest with me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, these Gentlemen know I speak Truth.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Tis very true indeed, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Well, since it happens so, I like it the better; for to say Truth, I had fix'd my Eye on you at my first Entrance.
Ah! wou'd 'twere over once.
Methinks I long to have thee in my Arms.
Oh! How I would employ my Faculties,
And surfeit with delight.
What say you, Lady? Never stand to consider on't, but send for a Parson to say Grace, that I may fall to. Odds so, I'm very hungry—Very sharp set;
I long to be doing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, walk in, and refresh your self after your Journey. I was unmannerly not to ask you before.
Prudence, Come hither. See that all things are in readiness. Oh, Prudence! I am impatient to be alone with him. Exit Pru.
My Lord, you will excuse the Disorder you have found me in.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Never trouble your self about it. Join but your Forces with mine, and we'll beget a Race of People, that shall be immortal. A Race, that shall create a second War with Jove, and raise Olympus top equal with the Seat of him, that hurls the Thunder.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No more, my Lord. Pray walk in.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: All your Commands are absolute.

div2.stage: [Exit Viscount leading the Widow, who pushes out Phil.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Was there ever such a Piece of Fly-Flesh?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: The Rogue acted it to the Life, and came very seasonably to my Rescue.
Had he staid a Moment longer, I had been forc'd to have given up the Ghost.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That ever Nature should suffer such a Lump of Rubbish in the World for Men to stumble over.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Pox on her old mouldy Chops:
She's for engroising all to her self.
How she thrust her Niece in before her!
I'll in, and try to beckon her into the Garden, if you'll interpose, shou'd the Aunt miss her, and follow us.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! Would'st have me run into the Lion's Den, just when I have scap'd his Paw!
No, I have hazarded too much already to venture more, I thank you. I now have better Game in Chace.
You know pretty Mrs. Brittle, Sir Peter Pride's Daughter?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis the sweetest little Creature!
So Fair, so Witty, so Kind, and so Promising!

I'm just now sending this Letter, in order to appoint a Meeting with her. But her Husband is so jealous (as indeed I hope to give him Cause for't) his Eye is hardly ever off her. I am thinking what way it can be deliver'd without Suspicion. Let me see—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I'll take my Leave; for I find I interrupt your Meditations.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Farewel, my Friend; and may both our Wishes prosper. (Exit Cuningham.
Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Can'st thou contrive to carry this Letter to a young Gentlewoman, and bring an Answer, without being suspected? If thou dost, Jeffrey, thou shalt be well rewarded for thy Pains.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Is she Widow, Wife, or Maid, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why dost thou ask?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: For a private Reason I have.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well then, to satisfy thy Curiosity, Jeffrey, know she's a Wife; a Young, a Handsome, and a Melting one!
I am all Ecstasy, and impatient till I possess her.
Good Jeffrey, look on the Superscription, and about it with all Speed.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I dare not touch it:
Don't trust me with it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why so, good Jeffrey?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I say again, do not trust me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Reason, Jeffrey?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I don't care to meddle in a Cause, where there's a Process of Cuckoldom going forward.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prithee, why so?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I'll tell you. You must know, Sir, I love Prudence, my Lady Laycock's Woman, and I believe there's no Love lost between us; nor do I know how soon we may exchange our Persons for better and for worse. Now, Sir, if I should be the Instrument (by carrying this Letter) of your making this honest Man a Cuckold, who knows but, in return of such a monstrous Deed, it may be my own Case next; therefore, Sir, I don't care to meddle in't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Give me the Letter again; I did but try thee. Thy Master, indeed, has often told me, how scrupulous thou wert about these Matters, but I ne'er believ'd it till now. Stick to thy Principles, and be what thou deserv'st, thou mayst come to Good at last. I have no farther Service at present. Prithee leave me, I have Business of Moment. (Exit Jeffrey.

I had been finely serv'd if I had sent this conscientious Rogue. What shall I do? The Viscount brought an ignorant Country Fellow up with him, that won't be suspected in the least. 'Tis well thought of; I'll entrust him, and send it immediately. Soft—Who comes here?—Oh! 'tis the Husband.
Your Servant, Mr. Brittle; is the Lady Laycock at home, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I believe she is.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I have a little Business, and must needs speak with her. Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: A little Business, quotha!
A fine Trade this doating old Widow drives; my House is become as common for all Commers and Goers, as the Mall or Spring-Garden: But I shall put a stop to it in a little time, I believe.

div2.stage: Enter Mrs. Brittle in haste, dress'd very airy; he stops her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: How now—Whither away in such haste?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I'm going abroad, Husband. Good bye.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, by your Leave, I'll know for what, and whither your sweet Ladyship is going?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Why, to the Play, sweet Husband.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Hum! to the Play.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Well, Good bye, Husband—I shall be too late, and then there'll be such crowding, I shan't get the first Row in the Box, for 'tis a new Play; and I had as lief not go, as sit behind.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, pray stay, if you please.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Indeed but I can't.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Indeed but you must not go, Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Indeed, Husband, but I shall.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I say again, you must not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Must not! Who shall hinder me?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, that will I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I say, No.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: But I say, Yes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Don't you pretend to't.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Don't you provoke me, I say. Is this the Trade you always intend to drive?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Yes indeed is it.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I say, No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: But I say, Yes. Do you think you shall keep me always stifling within Doors, where there's no body to be seen but your old fusty self? No, I'll to the Play, where there's all sorts of Company and Diversion; where the Actors represent all the Briskness and Gaiety of Life and Pleasure; where one is entertain'd with airy Beaux, and fine Gallants, which ogle, sigh, and talk the prettiest things in the World. Methinks 'tis rare to hear a young brisk Fellow court a handsome young Lass, and she all the while making such pretty dumb Signs: first turns aside to see who observes, then spreads her Fan before her Face, heaves up her Breasts, and sighs—at which he still swears he loves her above all the World—and presses hard his Suit; tells her, what Force her Beauty, her Wit, her Shape, her Mien, all join'd in one, are of. At which she blushing curtesies low, and to her self replies, What charming Words he speaks! his Person's Heavenly, and his Voice Divine. By your Leave, Husband, you make me stay long.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Not in the least—there will be no great miss of you, if you don't go. And now you talk of Gallants, bless us!—What a Dress is there! Do you think that fit for a Tradesman's Wife?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p:
No;—but I think it fit for Sir Peter Pride's Daughter, such as I am. I warrant you'd have me go abroad like one, thar sells Butter and Eggs—Or like one that cries, Come buy my dainty fine pickled Cucumbers: No, no, I'm resolv'd to dress—put on all the Airs I can—go
abroad—see and be seen—take my Fill of Pleasure, and not be shut up in a Nunnery, to pine and sigh, and waste my youthful Days in fruitless Wishes: No, I'm not so weary of my Life yet, tho▪ you do all you can to make me so. And I would have you to know, tho you have forc'd me to wed my self with old Age and ill Humours, I am not wedded to my Grave!—'tis time enough forty Years hence to think of that, and I have a great deal to do before that time comes; therefore I must, and I will go abroad.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Stir one Step if you dare (Spits in his Fist. If you go to that, I'll try who wears the Breeches, you or I. You shall stay at home, and keep me Company; I'll spoil your going to Plays, your Appointments, and your Intriegues—I'll make you know, that I am your Husband, and that you shall do what I please. Slife, What's here to do! What, have you forgot your Marriage Vows already? Pray, who am I? Am I not your Husband? Are you not married to me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No—You forc'd me; I never gave you my Consent in Word or in Deed. Could you think I was in Love with Avarice, with Age and Impotence?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Give me Patience! How! How!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No, you basely bought me of my Father and Mother.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Would I could sell thee again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Like a Slave you bought me, and so you intend to use me, were I Fool enough, but I'll see you hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, what will your sweet Ladyship do? I bought you, you say?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Yes; Had you my Consent? or did you once ask it? Or if you had, my Affections were plac'd elsewhere, and so they shall remain.
In spight of all your Threats and boasted Power! I'll not be us'd at this Rate!

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good lack!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I that am a Gentlewoman, descended from the worshipful Family of the Pride's by the Father's side—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay, so 'tis a sign by your Dress. Pride's, quotha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: And a Gentlewoman descended from the Honourable Family of the Laycock's by the Mother's side. (She Cries.
And to be us'd at this Rate by an old nasty Shopkeeper!

I might have married a Merchant, and have kept my Glass Coach, my tall Footmen in fine Liveries, have gone abroad when I pleas'd without Controul, visited Quality, nay, took Place of em at the Play-house, and met with Respect from the best; and is it come to this? But I'll to my honourable Father and Mother, and tell 'em all, who, I'm sure, won't suffer their Daughter to be thus abus'd. (Cries still.
I cannot, nor will not endure it any longer. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: This 'tis for a Tradesman to marry a Gentlewoman. A Curse on such Gentility! What shall I do? I shall be damnably plagu'd with her Father and Mother. Well, next Month I must take up in Bedlam; a Judgment, which every Citizen deserves, that marries above his Quality. (Exit.
WEll! What a Plague 'tis to be married!

I must incorporate with one above my Quality too, and not be content with something in my own Sphere, like one that had a Mind to live in Peace and Quietness, but nothing would serve me but a Gentlewoman, altho I took her with never a Tatter to her Back, forsooth; and now, I think, I'm fitted with a Vengeance. Would I were but fairly rid of her, and her Gentility once, the Devil should take all such Gentility before I'd ever concern my self with it again. But who have we here?
sp.stage: Enter Clodpole as out of Brittle's House, looking about him as afraid to be seen.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Hush!—Softly!—Mum—No body sees—Ha, ha, ha—No body sees! Softly!—Ods my Life, who's that?—Mum!—Not a Word.— (Is stealing off.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Friend, hist—Friend—Pray stay a little; What Business might you have in that House?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Wou'd you know now? Softly!—Not a Word. Ha, ha, ha, you understand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: But you must know—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do know already, but am not such a Fool to tell you. You shan't get a Word out of me. You understand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, very well, but—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly!—not a Word.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I know that; but who was you to speak with in that House?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly!—Can no body hear? For you must know, the old Cuckold of that House, they say, is damnably given to be jealous; I would not for ne'er so much he should see me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: You must not say any thing—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, not a Word.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: His Wife's a main pretty smirking Rogue, as a Man would wish to lay his Leg o'er.
Softly!—Is no body coming?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I'll warrant thee—Prithee go on.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: What? you want to know all, do you? But I'll not trust you. Mum! not a Word. You understand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I understand you well enough—but you may trust me, I shan't say a Word.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why luck now!—Ha, ha, ha, Wou'd you, would you? But you shall get nothing out of me.
I'll warrant you'd have me tell you now, that I brought a Letter to the Gentlewoman of that House—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hum!

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And that I deliver'd it to none but her self—as I was order'd—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: You understand me?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, perfectly well.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And that I stay'd for an Answer—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, and I hope you got one?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Mum! not a Syllable! no body must know!—If it should come to the Knowledge of the Cuckold her Husband, 'twill spoil all.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh never fear.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: You'll say nothing of what I have told you?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, not a Word.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: For you must know, Mr. Lovemore charg'd me, when he sent me, to say never a Word.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Is the Gentleman's Name Lovemore, say you?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, very well; a tall, proper, handsome Man, and always very generous.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: The same, the same.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: And lives just—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: At the lower end of this Street on t'other side of the way, over against the Golden Ball.
I find you do know him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Know him! Why he's my very good Friend.
A Pox of all such Friendship. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Odd, he's a fine Gentleman as ever I met with in all my Life.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he's a very fine Gentleman indeed.
I wou'd the Devil had him. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: He gave me this Piece of Gold to carry a Letter for him, which I deliver'd to the Gentlewoman of that House but now.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, he's a very civil Gentleman; I have been long acquainted with him.
Well, and what Answer did you get
A very pleasing one, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly, you must not tell a Syllable of this to the Husband, nor that she'll send my Master an Answer, as soon as ever she can get the Cuckold out of the way. But no body must know. You understand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, I'll keep your Counsel, never fear.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: She bad me tell him, she'd meet him this Evening, if she can.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And that she's very sensibly ob—ob—obliged to him, for his Kindness to her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay, no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And takes it mighty kind of him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: She does.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Odd, she's a pretty Bit; and then there's a handsome Maid that waits upon her, and is Assistant to her in these Matters, one Dam—Damaris, I think they call her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay, like enough.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And you must know I like her hugely. She gave me Two or Three such loving Looks, that I am half persuaded she likes me. So that if my Master gets acquainted with the Mistress, I intend to strike in with her Maid.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, all but Reason.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: But no body must know of it.
You understand me.
Well, good bye to you. My Master will wonder I stay so long. Be sure you say nothing now.
You understand me. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do so; farewel.
Well, Barnaby Brittle, now thou see'st what comes of marrying of a Gentlewoman. I believe thou wilt be married to something else in a little time, if thou art not so already. (Points to his Head.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Peter Pride and Lady Pride.

sp.speaker: Sir Pet.
sp.p: You seem disorder'd, Son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: And I have Reason to be so, if ever any Man had. (Walks to and fro in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Good lack! And why so short, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I shall grow taller in a little time, Good Mother-in-law, if this Trade holds. (Points to his Head.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Explain your Meaning, Son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: 'Twill explain it self shortly. (Walks up and down.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What, is that Hat of yours nail'd on? Do you know who we are? And the Respect due to Persons of our Quality, good Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah! wou'd I did not; but now I know to my Sorrow, since you will have me speak, good Mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Will you never leave that saucy Word, of calling me Mother-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good Lord! Why what must I call you then?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You ought to say, Madam and Sir, when you speak to us; or when you speak of us, you should say, Sir Peter, and her Ladyship: For tho' you have married our Daughter, yet there is a great deal of distinction betwixt you and Persons of our Rank and Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Go to, it is enough for me to let him know his Duty, without your Instructions. Sure, I best know my self what to do. Son-in-law, you are an impudent Fellow to use us at this rate. How often must we put you in mind of your Duty and Respect, e'er you'll know it? Hence-forward learn to behave your self as you ought, or you shall hear on't in other sort of Terms. You must not think because you've married our Daughter, that we will be satisfied with such indifferent Ceremonies and Duty you might have paid, had you married one equal with your self; nor ought you indeed to say, your Wife, when you speak of our Daughter.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good lack!—Is not your Daughter my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: She is.—But you ought not to call her so.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I know that too well, now 'tis too late. I'd give a thousand Pounds she were not my Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: At it again? I tell you, tho' you have married her, yet as she is our Daughter, you must not treat her after that familiar way.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: You make me mad—Is not my Wife my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I tell you, tho' she be your Wife, you must not call her so. When you speak of her, as being our Daughter, you must say, Madam.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, Madam, then since it must be Madam, I did not care if she were a Dutchess, so I were but fairly rid of her.

Here's such a stir about your Gentility, and your Honour: But I believe if I had not married your Daughter, and with my good Money redeem'd your Estate, your Gentility had been left in the Mud—for all your great Families, and your nice Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Then do you think it no Honour to be ally'd to the Worshipful Family of the Pride's.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And to the Honourable Family of the Laycock's? Go, Clown. 'Tis a Shame our Daughter should be wedded to such a Brute. We have been told at what a rate you treat her. What is the Reason of it, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, you shall know, good Mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Again at that affronting way!
How often have you been told to say, Madam?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, Madam, then: I always forget these fine Words. But, Madam, if you wou'd please, Madam, to hear me speak, you shall know, Madam, whether I have not Cause to wish, I never had seen my Wi—your Daughter, Madam, if I must call her nothing else.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Well, Sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, in the first Place, I am in a fair way to be made a Cuckold, if I am not one already.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: How, Son-in-law? Have a Care what you say.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Believe me, what I say, I can make appear.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Do it then presently.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, she has just now receiv'd a Letter from her Gallant, and made an Appointment to meet him this Evening; and judge how small a time a Pair of Horns are a grafting.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: How came you to know this, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, just now—I caught the Fellow, that brought her the Letter, coming out of my House, and not knowing who I was, I got out of him all the Business; and that his Master, Mr. Lovemore—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Is that the Gentleman's Name?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, so his Man told me. I have often seen him taking a View about my House, and looking up to the Windows; and 'tis plain what his Designs were.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If this be true, I'll tear her Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Nay, if it be, this good Sword (never yet drawn in vain) shall do you Right.
Where is she, Son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Within, I'll warrant, studying what Excuse to make, to get abroad, and meet her Gallant.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll call her to answer for her self.
Be sure you wrong her not, Son-in-law. (Exit Lady.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I make no doubt but she is to be believ'd before me; and she ne'er wants Cunning to bring her self off, I'll say that for her, tho' the Case be ne'er so plain.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: By this good Light, if she dares be false to her Marriage Vows, she dies; and that base Rifler of her Fame shall bear her Company.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh! Here he comes; that Spoiler of my Honour; that's he.

div2.stage: Enter Lovemore. Sir Peter meets him. They stare each other i'th' Face.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Do you know who I am, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I don't well remember I ever had much Acquaintance with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I am call'd Sir Peter Pride.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It may be so: I've heard of you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: My Family, Sir, has stood these many Years with unblemish'd Fame and Honour.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Very likely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: How far you have endeavour'd to stain that spotless Fame, be judge your self.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, explain this Riddle.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I have a Daughter young, fair, well-bred, has Sense; she is indeed the Wonder of her Sex, and this Man, whom you see here, has the Honour to be married to her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah! 'Tis an Honour, that I cou'd have spar'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I'm told, that you endeavour to corrupt her Honour, and defile her Marriage-Bed. Sir, I have had the Honour to command abroad, and with Success, both to my King and my Country—As have also the Chief Part of all our great Race; even from William the Conqueror, to this present Reign, have our unquestion'd Glories stood a Pattern to our yet rising Fame: And he who dares presume to rob us of that precious Jewel, Honour, must not think to scape unpunish'd, tho' with the Hazard o'th' last Drop of Blood, that is lest, to wash off the Stain. My Daughter's Honour, Sir, is as dear to me, as this vital Air, by which I breath and live.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray Sir, who told you this?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, whate'er I say, I can quote my Author for it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Then who-ever told you is a Rascal; and were he here, I'd ram the Lie down his Throat, or make him eat a Piece of my Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Why he told me—This Man—Her Husband here justified it to my Face, and said he had Proof.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How, Sir! Did you frame this abominable Falshood? 'Tis well you have the Honour to be ally'd to this worthy Knight, Sir Peter Pride, here; or you should know what it is to father such a Lie upon a Man of my Reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Oh! Here comes my Daughter.

div2.stage: Enter Lady Pride, Mrs. Brittle, and Damaris.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Did you, Madam, tell your Husband a strange Story, that I should make Love to you, and endeavour'd to corrupt your Honour?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I tell him! Why, when did you make Love to me, Sir? I assure you, had you let me know of your Passion, it shou'd not have gone unrewarded. Pray, next time you send, let it be one that knows how to take more Care. However, you have no great Reason to despair; for since he complains without any manner of Reason, I am resolv'd he shall have Cause. Therefore if you do love me, Sir, pray let me know it, and I do assure you, you shall not want Encouragement. He shall not use me at this rate for nothing.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, believe me, 'tis all a Riddle to me; for, till this Hour, I never heard any thing mention'd like it: I am an absolute Stranger to it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you hear that, you Clown? Are you not asham'd to abuse a Gentlewoman continually, without any Cause?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What is the Meaning of this, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Pray, do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Troth, Son-in-law, you are a very impudent Fellow.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hear me but speak?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: You shall not speak.
We have heard too much already.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I am sure Damaris knows, I never have any body comes near me, but such as himself; nor ever receiv'd any Message, either by Letter, or otherwise—

I never committed any Crime against him, that I know of, unless sitting by my self all Day, and poring over two or three good Books be an Offence. Speak, Damaris, did I ever give him any Cause for these Suspicions, and this Usage? Thou know'st all I say or do.

sp.speaker: Damaris.
sp.p: Madam, I know no Reason; nor can I bear to see the Hardship you endure! Like a barbarous Man as he is—To abuse so good a Lady! so Virtuous, so Innocent, and so Pious a Lady! I am sure it makes me weep to think on't—I am afraid he'll break her Heart in a little time, if—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, you Jade, or I'll make you feel my double Fist. You are not a Gentlewoman—
I may do what I please with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Father! (Cries.
I am not able to endure this any longer.
Never was any Woman abus'd as I am.
I beg you will do me Justice, for I can bear it no longer. (Exit crying.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Damaris, let's follow her, and endeavour to comfort her. Oh, thou Clown, to use a Gentlewoman with so much Cruelty!

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I fear he'll be the Death of her at one time or another. (Exeunt Lady Pride and Damaris.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What do you think of all this, Sir?
Are not you a very pretty Fellow?
Come hither, Son-in-law, ask this Gentleman Pardon, for the Affront you have put upon him in belying of him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: How! ask his Pardon, that would have made me a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir Peter, pray—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I say no more Words: He has wrong'd a Gentleman; and the least he can do, is begging Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: 'Tis very well! He offends, and I must ask Pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: No matter for that, you hear he denies it; and 'tis enough, if a Gentleman unsays what he has said.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: So that if I catch him making me a Cuckold, and he denies it, I must not believe it, because a Gentleman said it.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I say, you shall ask Pardon: Therefore no more Words, but do't.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I shall run mad.
Well, what must I do?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Come hither: Take your Hat off— Kneel down, and say after me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, since it must be so— (Kneels.
This 'tis to be marry'd to a Gentlewoman, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Sir, I ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Sir, I ask your Pardon. (In the same Tone▪

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: For the Affront I have put upon you.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: For the Affront I have put upon you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: By falsly accusing you—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: How! falsely accusing him!

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I say no more Words. Say after me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Say after me.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Accusing you, of having a Design to corrupt my Wife's Honour.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Accusing you of Truth—And having a Design to corrupt my Wife's Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: For which, knowing my self in the wrong, I do ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: For which, knowing my self not in the wrong, I'm forc'd to ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, Sir, upon Sir Peter Pride's Account▪ I am content to pass it by this time: But let me hear no more Complaints. (Brittle rises, and runs off.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Sir, now all is well, I humbly take my Leave. (Exit Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Was there ever such a lucky Rogue as I? For her to encourage me to make Love to her before her Husband's Face!
Nay, and before her Father and Mother too!
Oh, I am all on Fire till I have her in my Arms!
But soft! who comes here?
Well, my little Scout, what News? How fares my Friend? Is Philadelphia kind? Where's thy Lady?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Where▪e'er her Person is, I'm sure her best Thoughts are still employ'd on you. And however she may pretend a Passion for Mr. Cuningham, she loves none but you. Pray, Sir, do but try her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh racking Thought! I'd rather make Love to a Convocation of Cats at a Witch's Up-sitting, than but speak to her. Where's my Friend? Oh! here he comes, and his fair Consort.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Be not so cruel to say, you want the Power: If we neglect this Opportunity, which kindly presents it self, the next perhaps may not be ours.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Would you then have me dispose of my self without my Aunt's Consent? Do not urge me to that, since I have promised not to wed without it.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I ask not her Consent, but yours: Grant me but that, and leave the rest to Time and Chance.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Madam, how can you deny him that, since I know you love him?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Ha! Oh, the charming Sound!
And will you not consent to make me happy?
Or do you not believe I love you?
By all those Fires that burn within my Soul, I swear—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Hold! Hold, Sir! You have sworn enough already to corrupt a whole Nunnery of Sighing, Praying and Wishing young Votaries. Why don't you give him your Hand, since he has your Heart. I believe you love to hear him swear and—Give him your Hand, or, I'll discover all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well, there 'tis then; (Gives her Hand to Cuningham.
But I promise nothing else. I fear I have given too much already.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, never! never! I'll pay thee back so vast a store of Love and Constancy, as shall weary thee with still receiving.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, your Aunt's behind you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ha! My Aunt! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Madam, but give me your Hand.
I'll bring all off. (Pretends to tell her Fortune▪

This Line seems to Point out some unexpected Cross: And this Line thwarting the Line of Life, signifies a retir'd Life; and this joining with it, shews you'll be in Danger of ending the latter part of your Days in a Nunnery. (Widow behind them.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: How, Mr. Cuningham! Can you tell Fortunes?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I understand a little Palmistry, Madam, and can give a Ghess at Physiognomy.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: 'Tis very well.

When I enter'd first, I thought you had been making
Love to my Neice: I am glad to find it otherwise. But where's the Viscount?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: In the next Room, Madam.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll wait upon him: I'd feign try whether his Inside be answerable to his outward Appearance.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Nay, prithee stay; I can assure you, he is not to be equall'd either in Person or Discourse.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: He is indeed a fine proper Man, as one would wish to see.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why, really his Lordship has Parts.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You and Prudence go find him out, and bear him Company awhile; I'll wait on him immediately, tell him. You, Sir, may go with 'em, if you please. (To Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, most willingly.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! You won't leave me? (Aside to Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, but I will; dost think I'll stay to endure a second Hell? For if there be one upon Earth, 'tis being left alone with her.
Madam, Your Ladyship shall ever command me. (To the Widow.
Come, Lady, if you please, the Honour of your fair Hand. (To Phil.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What will become of me now? (Aside.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Cuningham, I have long'd for some time to be alone with you, that I might speak more freely to you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis too great an Honour.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I wonder, Sir, you never think of Marrying?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam, as yet I dare not think on't.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! Pray, why so?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Because I have not well consider'd it; and I have been told, 'tis a dangerous Undertaking, without having well thought before-hand.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, why should you think so?
I'll vow 'tis an odd Thought, Sir, for one of your Understanding: Why, Sir, I'll tell you.

I have had Three Husbands, and yet I have no great Reason to complain: Tho' in my last Husband's time, I had not altogether that real Satisfaction, as I had with the other Two; for to deal freely with you, Sir, my Husband Sir Oliver Laycock, though he was a very well-bred Man, yet he had his Humours sometimes, and would be a little given to Jealousy, so that I seldom led a quiet Hour when the Fit was upon him. But in my first Husband's Days, sure never Woman liv'd so happy! I would not a-been unmarried to have had all the Riches of the Earth laid at my Feet: But when I married with Sir Oliver, and had once seen his Temper, nothing I had in the World but what I would a given to a been free again; and indeed in my Passion I often vow'd never (if please Heav'n Sir Oliver died) to marry any more.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Twas rashly done.

But no doubt, were there that Man fitting to merit your Favour, and equally deserving your Person and your Estate, and one whom your Ladyship could like, you might perhaps be persuaded to break your Vow, and venture once again.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'll swear I hardly think it, and yet one don't know how one may be tempted; tho' if I were to be persuaded, (and I will not forswear any thing) I know not any one, that can so soon persuade me to it as you, Mr. Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Death and the Devil! What have I brought upon my self! (Aside.
Oh Madam! You make me blush.
But Madam! How cou'd you with Honour put off the Viscount, who you know loves you, and is come on purpose to marry you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, I intend him for my Niece you must know, who no doubt will be much better pleas'd with the Change. For, to say Truth, Mr. Cuningham, I have always had more, than a common Esteem for you, and for your Behaviour; and have long since resolv'd, that if I do alter my Condition, you are the Man alone I have plac'd my Thoughts upon.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: You make me blush, Madam.
Wou'd I were a League under-ground, or in any Hell but this. (Aside.
You cannot sure. (To her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I vow 'tis true, and yet—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Hear me but speak, Madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: 'Tis odd, that Love shou'd over-power People at so strange a rate.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: But I should be unjust to my Friend, who I know loves you dearer, than his Life.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh dear! Who's that I beseech you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Mr. Lovemore, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Mr. Lovemore! I'll swear I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh Madam! 'tis but too true, as will appear I'm afraid, when he knows you place your Affections on any other Man.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'll vow you much surprize me, Mr. Cuningham; but how came you to know it?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oft has he begg'd me to bear him Company in some lonely Place, where he wou'd sigh, and tell such things of his distressed Passion, as wou'd have mov'd the most obdurate Heart; and when I ask'd him, why he did not acquaint your Ladyship with his Love, he would sigh, with Arms a-cross, as if his Heart would force its way through his Breast, and cry, Oh that's my Grief, my Friend, I cannot—dare not tell her! for should I attempt it once, and meet her scorn, (for oh! thou know'st her Vow) I shou'd be for ever lost.
Then ran o'er a thousand Tales of Love, so soft, so moving, and how he priz'd you, that cannot be express'd by any, except one, who loves like him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, if it be so—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: If it be so! were your Ladyship to observe his distracted Throes, you'd pity him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: But why should he not declare it to me?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: That's what I tell him, Madam;
Urging that your Ladyship—But mum! who have we here?

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Ha! Whispering! And so close!
I like it not.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: The Viscount! this is unlucky.
He looks disturb'd! Good Sir, some other time we'll end this Discourse. (to Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Ha! What are you, Sir? that thus dares to encroach upon my Territories, and invade my Right?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Nay, pray my Lord, be not displeas'd. This Gentleman, you must know, has a Law suit depending, and is come to entreat a Line of Commendation from me to my Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Enough; I do believe all you can say. Ah! those Eyes of yours! What Looks are there! they enflame my very Soul.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Ah, Prudence, how I long to be alone with him.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: I am impatient of this Delay, when shall we be married?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Pray moderate your Passion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: What, you are afraid of that melancholy Gentleman, that stands so silently there.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Speak softly, I am afraid he hears you▪ Sir.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: What care I if he does.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, the Dancers you spoke for, wait without.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Let 'em enter. Will you please to sit, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Prudence, go tell Mr. Lovemore, I'd speak with him this Evening. (Exit Prudence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: —you may take a Turn in the Garden. And, Sir, if you think it no Trouble, you may bear her Company. (To Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam, most willingly. (Exit with Phil.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why are you so melancholy, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Nothing that's worth the naming. But if you'll walk into the next Room, I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: My Lord, you are a Man of Honour, and I dare trust my self with you.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Madam, if I deserve it not, may you always keep a Whip and a Bell, to scourge me from you like a Cur.

div2.stage: Enter Clodpole and Damaris: He gives her a Letter.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: YOU are a fine Spark, are you not, to discover all the Business, and let it come to my Master's Hearing?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why ay, that's true, as you say; but who wou'd have thought that he could have known it! But now to our own Business, Damaris—
Dost thou not love me, Damaris?
Thou know'st I love thee with all my Heart.
Good lack! How it beats!—Odd, you may hear it thump all over the House.
Damaris—How can'st thou be so hard-hearted?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pshaw! Prithee leave fooling.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: One Kiss, Damaris, to revive me.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pray, Clodpole, be civil.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris!—Canst thou not spare a little Bit afore-hand?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Of what, Fool?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why, of—Odd, you know well enough▪ What, I need not name it to thee.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I know nothing of the Matter.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Ay, but you do. Why, I ask but a little tiney, tiney Bit. Do, prithee now do.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll see you at the Devil first.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Do, Damaris—Spare but a Bit now; and bate me as much on the Wedding-Night.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: No, I thank you, good Clodpole: I have too often been snapt that way already. (Aside.
But see—yonder comes my Lady and my Master— Step with me into the next Room, he must not see you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Ay, any where, any where: Quickly, good Damaris. (Exit.

div2.stage: Enter Barnaby Brittle and Mrs. Brittle.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I tell you again, that Marriage is a very sacred Thing, and ought not to be profan'd at this Rate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: What do you tell me of Marriage, I have other things to mind.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p:
Truly, I do believe as much; that's the truest Word you ever spoke: But I think you ought to mind what I say. Am I not your Husband? And
are not you bound in Duty by that Tye, to be obedient and just in all your Ways?
sp.stage: Enter Lovemore on the other side bowing. She sees him, and Curtesies to him.
sp.p: What's that for? What, do you banter me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Keep your Instructions for those that want 'em, my Thoughts are other ways employ'd.

div2.stage: (She Curtesies, Lovemore bows. Brittle sees him not, and thinks she does it in scorn to him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: What, you are practising your Airs against you meet your Gallant, are you? And trying how to behave your self to him? But I shall spoil your Design, I shall. (He Bows, she Curtesies again.
Leave off your Tricks with a Vengeance, and mind what I say to you. (Lovemore keeps Bowing to her.
Again, don't provoke me; I say, don't; if you do, you may chance to repent it. I say, that Marriage—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I know it, Dear; you need say no more.
sp.stage: (She takes Brittle round the Neck, and beckons Lovemore, who comes and kisses her Hand over her Husband's Shoulders all the while.
sp.p: You know I love you dearly, by this I do. (Kisses him.
Why will you not be satisfied? Had I the World to give, it cou'd not make me more happy than this Minute. (Lovemore still kisses her Hand.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah dissembling Crocodile?
What, now you think to wheedle me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Be satisfied with this: Hence forward, if you deserve it, I give you my Heart for ever, which, till this Minute, I did not think to do.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah, would 'twere in your Power to keep your Word.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
