sp.p: Indeed I will, let that content you▪ and learn to merit that rich Jewel, which this Moment I put within your Power.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: If thou would'st be thus kind always, how happy should I be! But that's impossible! Would you but think sometimes upon the Vow you made in Church, that solemn Vow of Marriage, 'twould put you in Mind of your Duty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: How can I think of any thing, when you will not give me leave so much as to peep abroad for Air? Do you think a Woman can ever be in a good Humour, that is lock'd up, and kept from what she likes? But I'm resolv'd to bear it no longer.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good lack! What's your Mind chang'd already? I thought 'twas too good to last long.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: But hence-forward you shan't think to make a Fool of me at this rate. I'll find a way to get out, for all your Spies; and then look to't—I'll use you as you deserve.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Tempt me no farther, I beseech you; if you do, I shall use you as you deserve. Patience! and I have need enough of it at this time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I'm resolv'd to encourage every Man, that makes Love to me. I'll kiss and be wanton, since you provoke me to't. Love, and be belov'd—and not be subject to the nasty Humours of an old Jealous—I can't find a Name bad enough for thee.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Odd, I've a great Mind to spoil that handsome Face. The Devil tempts me strangely: I must be gone; for if I stay, I shall certainly be provok'd to do her a Mischief. (Runs off.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I waited till my Master was gone, to deliver you this Letter; Madam, Mr. Lovemore's Man is within, and waits for an Answer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Give it me, Damaris, quickly.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I need not bid you read it, since you know from whom it comes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis extremely pretty, Damaris. I'll in, and write an Answer presently. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So she has snapt the Bait at the first Angling; how she'll get clear of the Hook, I know not. Ha! he's here himself!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pretty Mrs. Damaris, I'm glad to see you. Is your Lady within?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, writing an Answer to your Letter, I suppose. You see, I deliver'd it with Care.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, I understand you; there's for thy Pains.

div2.stage: (Gives her Money, she puts her Hand behind her, and takes it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir, by no means. But since you will have it so, pray command me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Can'st thou contrive to let me speak with thy Mistress?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: If you please, Sir, I'll shew you to her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Thou wilt oblige me for ever.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Hist! Damaris!—Odd, I shall have a rare Wife of her, if she gets Money so fast. Here's a piece of Gold got without the least Trouble, as they say. But softly!—Who have we here?
Oh! are you there, Mr. Babbler? You are a pretty Fellow indeed; you have made fine Work! You cannot be told a Secret, but you must tell the Husband presently. You understand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Who, I tell the Husband, Friend!

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Yes, you; but I'll see you hang'd before you shall get any thing more out of me. You have made fine Work! All's discover'd!—The Cuckold, her Husband, knows all the Business.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, but—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: You may as well hold your Tongue, for you shan't get a Word out of me.
No, no, I have found you out, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: This Fellow may be useful to affirm it to her Father and Mother. I'll try to bribe him. (Aside.
sp.stage: (Puts his Hand in his Pocket to give him Money.
sp.p: Why look you, Friend, I'm sorry this Matter is—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Mum! You understand me.
I know what you'd say now, but 'twill not do. You'd have me to tell you what I know, but Mum!—Softly!—Not a Word. I'll warrant, you'd have me tell you what Answer she gave to the Letter.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, Friend; but—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly!—You shall get nothing out of me. You think I'll tell you now, that the Wife promis'd to meet him, and that they are together now in that Room; but I'm not such a Fool. No, no, you'll tell the Husband again; you cannot be secret, and so good bye to you. You shall get nothing out of me. You understand me. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p:
I'm sorry I can't make that use of him as I intended; but however, he has discover'd something to me, that may do as well. He said her Gallant is with her now; I'll listen. (Goes to the Door.
Oh Sadness! 'tis but too true. Here's fine Doings. But I'll send for her Parents. Now they shall see who's in the wrong, and who's in the right. She can't scape me now, unless the Devil assist her; and see where they come in a lucky Hour.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Peter Pride and Lady P.
sp.p: Father-in-law, you're welcome; and you, Madam. I'm glad you are come, I was just going to send for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Why, what's the Matter, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Now you see what a fine Daughter you have.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What! more Complaints! What is the Reason of all this?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Do but hear me, and you shall know.
Here has been her Gallant, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Son-in-law, I'll not believe it. Will you never leave this fooling? We'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no; I knew you wou'd never believe a Word I say; but she can be credited, because she's a Gentlewoman, forsooth. Now you shall see what a Gentlewoman I have got for a Wife. I have her fast now, fast in that Room with her Gallant, and that I hope will convince you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis false, thou base Villain. I know she scorns to do so base a thing.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Pray now don't believe me, but walk in: If you find it not true, never mind any thing I say, as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Lead, Son-in law. If I find 'em together, by this good Sword they both shall die.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But if 'tis not so, which I do believe 'tis only your Jealousy again, look to your self, Son-in-law, I'll suffer these Affronts no longer.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: If they are not there now, I am a very Villain.
Come along—Softly— (They all go in.

div2.stage: SCENE Changes to a Chamber, and discovers Lovemore, Mrs. Brittle, and Damaris.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You question your own Power, when you mistrust my Honour, Madam. Such Charms can never want Force to allay all Thoughts of wronging so much Goodness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I do believe you to be a Man of Honour, and hope you will not wrong my good Opinion.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Peter, Lady Pride and Brittle, behind them. They grow enrag'd to see 'em together, and make Signs of Revenge. Sir Peter lays his Hand upon his Sword.
sp.p: Therefore meet me this Evening at the Garden-Door about Nine, and there we'll discourse farther: If I find what you say be real, perhaps I may be prevail'd upon to venture farther.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, you bless me! (Kisses her Hand.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Have a little Patience—
Let's draw nearer, and hear what they say.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Oh Madam! Madam! my Master, Sir Peter, and my Lady, are just behind you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Ha! undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What will become of me then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Let me alone to bring it off.
Be not you surpriz'd at any thing I say, but seem to humour it.

I'll hear no more. (Seems to be angry with Lovemore. What do you tell me of your being amaz'd! Did you ever see any thing in me, that cou'd encourage you to believe I was that Woman you took me for? I'll warrant you thought, because I seem'd to give you Encouragement before my Husband Yesterday, when he had enrag'd me, that I was in earnest?

div2.stage: (They over-hear, seem angry, and to threaten Brittle, who pretends by Signs to excuse himself.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What mean you, Madam? (Confusedly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: But you will find your self deceiv'd: For tho' my Husband gives me Provocations to use him at any rate, yet, Sir, I'd have you to know, I scorn Revenge; and will not be brib'd to stain my Honour, tho' all the Wealth of the whole World were laid at my Feet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you hear that, Son-in-law?
sp.stage: They still threaten, he looks sneakingly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No, Sir, my honourable Parents brought me up with the strictest Care; taught me the nice Paths that lead to Everlasting Fame and Glory: And he, who dares attempt to make me lose my Way, deserves to be us'd thus, thus, and thus, Sir.

div2.stage: (Gets near Sir Peter, snatches his Cane, and runs at Lovemore, who gets behind Brittle. She beats Brittle unmercifully, while Lovemore gets off.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, Hold! Hold! What, will you murder me? (Brittle rubs his Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Troth, Son-in-law, she serv'd you right.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You have not half what you deserve;
And I cou'd find in my Heart to—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Let him alone: I'll correct him.
Son-in-law, You are a very impudent Fellow to use your Wife thus. What can you say for your self? (Feels his Arms and Head.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Say for my self! Why, I say, 'tis all a Trick—And a Contrivance to blind the Matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Is it not plain, you have wrong'd her? Do you not see she is a virtuous and a good Wife?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Too good for him, a Clown.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, well, I am over-reach'd, I see.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Son-in-law, I charge you let me hear no more of this. And instantly ask your Wife's Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Oh! let him alone; 'twill be to no purpose.
I'm a little out of Order.
Damaris, Lead me to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I say follow her, and ask her Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: If I do, the Curse of Cuckoldom fall upon me. (Runs out another way.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah, graceless Clown.
Come, Sir Peter, let's follow, and see how she does.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Madam, my Lady presents her Service to your Ladyship and Sir Peter; and would desire your good Company at a Ball the Viscount treats her with.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Our humble Thanks to her Ladyship.
We will not fail to wait upon her.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Lovemore! I have expected you; I am glad you're come.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, Your Ladyship does me too much Honour.
Pray, Madam, when saw you Mr. Cuningham?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! He has told me all.

And now you talk of Mr. Cuningham—Prudence,
go find out my Niece, and have an Eye over her. (Exit Pru.
Well, Sir, I am sorry you shou'd make your self so great a Stranger to me. In such Cases I am not ungrateful. And where Love is real, there's a double Obligation.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ha! What does she mean by Love and double Obligations? (Aside.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I see indeed you seem to be in some Disorder, that I should know it; but had you let me known it sooner, I shou'd perhaps have sav'd you a great many Sighs and Heart-Akings, which you Bashfulness has caus'd.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sure she's mad! [Aside.] Madam—

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: And yet 'tis never too late to serve a Friend, and one that loves so dearly: Nor am I yet so far engag'd, but I can pity, nay make Return, when Love is sincere, and so constant.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, you much amaze me!
Nor can I ghess what you drive at!

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Ah, dear Sir! I know you are unwilling to let me know it: But shall I be sincere in asking you one Question?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Most freely; so it be not any thing that leads me farther into the dark.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Do you not love me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Love you, Madam! Why truly I hate no body.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Well, but love me so, that it much disturbs you, and that you fear I am engag'd to another.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: The Devil take me if I ever lov'd you, or can think what you wou'd be at.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Nay, I was told you would deny it,
But pray, Sir, tell me truly; for indeed, Sir, I am sorry you should suffer for my Sake. And should you do otherwise than well, I vow it would be a Means of giving me disquiet as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, who told you this?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Your Friend Mr. Cuningham, who is much concern'd for you, Sir. And since you find it is discover'd, you need not be asham'd to own the Truth.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, to deal freely with you, yov're abus'd; for hang me if ever I had a thought that way, nor do I love you, or ever can.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: You're pleas'd to be merry, Sir; but I must tell you, I have observ'd it in your Looks; and since it is so, own it boldly to the World, and I promise you, I'll not be asham'd, nor disown mine. Come, come, Mr. Lovemore, you must not deny me that; for since I dare own it, why should you think it still amiss?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well! Since all must out, prepare to hear me.

Mr. Cuningham has begun, and I must make an End. You must know, Madam, Mr. Cuningham loves you to that degree himself, that he's asham'd, knowing how near a-kin he is to you, to let you know it, and so has form'd this Story upon me, the better to make for him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Mr. Cuningham a-kin to me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, your Nephew, your Brother's Son, whom he had in Paris by Madam D'Olone, but for some Reason he since has chang'd his Name.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, you surprize me much! My Brother in Paris I heard had a Son, but what became of him I know not.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, this Cuningham, my Friend, has the Misfortune (Misfortune I think it, and he thinks so too, because he loves so dearly) to be related to you.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'm sorry, if he does love so well, that he shou'd be so near a-kin.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Madam, Mr. Cuningham is just come in.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll leave you, Madam, for I have a little Business that I must dispatch—Besides, 'twou'd not be convenient for me to interrupt what Disputes you two may have.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant.
sp.stage: (As he goes out, meets Cuningham ent'ring.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Had you no body to put your Tricks on, but me?
But I think I have been even with you. (Exit Love.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What can he mean?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Mr. Cuningham, you do not deal like a Friend by me; you might have trusted me with a Secret of greater weight.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I do not understand you, Madam!
What has he been saying to her? (Aside.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: You knew one Mrs. D'Olone, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What shall I say now? (Aside.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Was your Brother then Mrs. D'Olone's Husband, Madam, and Mr. Cuningham's Father?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Who bid you speak? Yes he was. What then?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, I begin to smoke it. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nothing, Madam, but then Mr. Cuningham is your Nephew.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Indeed, I wish he were not; but since it is so, we must be satisfied with our Fate, Mr. Cuningham: Tho' you are much to blame, Sir, you did not let me know it sooner before Matters went so far.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam, I confess my Fault, and do ask your Ladyship's Forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Cuningham, since you are my Nephew, we may venture to embrace without a Blush.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Is Mr. Cuningam your Nephew, Madam?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Yes, Mistress Pert, what then?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Then he's my Cousin, and I may embrace him too. (Runs and embraces each other.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Ay, my dear, dear Cousin.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why how now saucy, impertinent Slut. How dare you take this Liberty?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why, is there any Harm in embracing one's own Cousin?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Get you in, Hussy, and dare not to come but when I call you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: He's none of your Cousin, Madam.
sp.stage: (Aside to Phil. as she goes out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I know it. I met Mr. Lovemore laughing by the way, who told me all. Adieu, my dear Cousin

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: My charming Cousin, farewel.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'll swear, Mr. Cuningham, you'll spoil that Girl.
Methinks you embrac'd her something of the hardest. (Seems disturb'd.

I call her Girl, and yet she's near five and twenty—But as I was going to tell you, Sir, You must know, this Brother was not indeed my own Brother, but something a kin afar off: He was my first Husband's first Wife's Brother, and no kin to me. But because my Husband us'd to call him Brother, I would sometimes do so too; and by this Means was thought, by those that knew no other, to be my Brother.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Then he is not so near a-kin, but he may marry your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh!— (Sighs.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why, truly, Mr. Cuningham—

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Sir, your Lawyer bid me tell you, your Cause is just now coming on; and if you do not appear, you'll be non-suited.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Dear Sir, do not neglect your Business, nor let your being a-kin trouble you.
When next I see you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! Wou'd I had never seen you, then I'd been happy; but where the Tye of Blood bars our Hopes, there's nothing but Despair in view. Madam, farewel.
Find some way to excuse me, you Dog, or I'll cut your Throat. (To Jeffrey as he goes out.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: What shall I say? (Aside.
My Master has begun a Lie, and I must end it.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Come hither, Jeffrey. Dost think thy Master loves me so well as he says?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I believe he loves your Ladyship but too well! But Mr. Lovemore dies, unless you take pity on him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Dost think he loves me better, than thy Master?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! They ought not to be nam'd together. Mr. Lovemore, poor Gentleman, is perfectly beside himself about it.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Didst ever hear 'em talk about me?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: A thousand times. Mr. Lovemore can talk of nothing else.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: 'Tis strange he should deny it to me.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: You must know, Madam, my Master was in Love else-where.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: How Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: If your Ladyship will have Patience to hear me out, you shall know the whole Story.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Why, you must know, Madam, my Master had the Misfortune to quarrel with a Gentleman, who urg'd him to fight; my Master kill'd him: Upon which he was forc'd to change his Habit and his Name—From Cuningham to Boutefeu. But thinking it not safe to stay here, fled; and in his Journey happen'd into a Viscount's Castle, but the Viscount was gone a Journey. However, this Viscount had a very beautiful Sister, that had the Command in her Brother's Absence; she entertain'd my Master very splendidly: At last he fell in love with her, and she with him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Methinks she was very forward, Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: She was so indeed, Madam; for before my Master left her, she prov'd with Child.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: How! with Child, and not married, Jeffrey!

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: My Master had promis'd her Marriage, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh, the impudent Creature! And thy Master was to blame, not to keep his Word, Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Not at all, Madam, when you have heard all. You must know, my Master grew jealous of one of the Servants, as indeed he had Reason: And one Day pretended to ride out, and he shou'd not return that Night, but left me to let him in, when the Servants were all a-bed, which I did. Going up to this Lady's Bed-Chamber, and not being expected that Night, found the Servant in Bed with her.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Unheard of Impudence!
At first I was going to condemn thy Master, for deceiving a young Creature; but 'tis likely he was not the first, that had to do with her.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Very likely so, Madam. Next Day my Master was for packing up his Awls, and for going; she cry'd, and urg'd his stay, and his Vows to marry her.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: He had been more to blame to have done that.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: In the mean time the Viscount return'd, found his Sister in Tears, wou'd know the Reason, was told all. He swore, if ever he could get hold of him, he'd hang him at his Castle Gate, but my Master was got off safe. What it will come to, it they should ever meet, I know not, but fear the Event.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A well invented Lye the Rogue has told. (Aside. What was this Viscount's Name?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: The Viscount Sans▪Terre, I think he was call'd.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: The Viscount Sans-Terre!

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why, he's in this House.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: What, in this very House?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: In this very House; in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Ah, my poor Master! he's but a dead Man, if he's found; for he'll certainly be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Here he comes. Hold your Peace!

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: My Lord, your Servant. I have a Question to ask of you.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: What shall I do to make him understand? (Aside.
Humour her in all she says, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Ask what thou wilt, I'll deny thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: You had a Sister.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: I had so. Go on.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: And she was unfortunately wrong'd by a base Fellow.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: What must I say next?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: 'Twas not well done to debauch her, and then to leave her; but Woe be to him, if your Lordship catch him.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: If ever I do find the Son of a Whore, I'll hang him at my Castle Gate.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: He was very much to blame indeed; but yet, all things consider'd, he was not in all the Blame neither, counting what a Trick she play'd him. He had reason to question, whether the Child was his, or not.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: I'm quite at a Loss. Oh! tell me what I must say next? (Faints into Jeffrey's Arms, who instructs him.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Take it in your Ear, my Lord. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Help, Prudence, my Lord faints.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, don't come too near, but give him Air. (Prudence and Jeffrey tell him what to say.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh! he recovers.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Give me a little Air. I beg your Pardon, I never hear my Sister's Wrongs mention'd, but it puts me in Disorder; but if ever I do light upon the Villain, Woe be to him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'll try to get his Pardon. (Aside.
My Lord, methinks her Crime being the greatest, you might pardon him.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: What! Pardon him, that has deflower'd my Sister, got her with Child of a Bastard, and stain'd the Honour of our great Family! No, tho' all the World should plead for him, I'll not forgive it; he dies.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Good, my Lord, for my Sake.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: 'Tis all in vain, Lady. I'm told he's now in this House, and has chang'd his Name. But if I find him— (Draws.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh hold, my Lord, I must save him. (Aside. My Lord, I have but one Request more.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: 'Twill be in vain: I'll have Revenge.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Tell him you'll marry him, Madam, and try what that will do. (Aside to the Widow.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Give me this Gentleman's Life, and I am content to be your Wife; otherwise—

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: 'Tis a hard Request; but to shew how much I love you, upon that Condition I grant it.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Or, if you think sit, you shall have my Niece Philadelphia, and with her I'll give you ten thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Do you think my Love so poor, that 'twill be brib'd? Nay, then I recal my Promise. He dies this Hour. (Draws and searches about.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh, pray my Lord, forbear; my Lady did it but to try you! See, you fright her.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, since it must be so, my Chaplain is within, I'm contented he shou'd make us one, make good but your Promise.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: I confirm it here. (Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: My Lord, the Dancers are ready to begin, and all the Company stay for you.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Let 'em enter, and begin when they please.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Peter Pride, Lady Pride, Lovemore, Mrs. Brittle, Cuningham and Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I rely upon your Promise.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen and Ladies, pray sit.

div2.stage: After the Dance, Enter Barnaby Brittle, who runs after his Wife; they get between, he gets hold of her, and carries her off after Speaking.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Here's fine Doings! But I'll spoil your Sport. What! my House is become a Music-house, is it? But, Gentlewoman, I have something to say to you within.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: How now! What's the Meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I say, my Wife—

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: What of your Wife?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Shall keep me Company, if you please.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: You Company!

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What's the matter with the Fellow? ha!

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Come along, I say. What's here to do! Is not a Man's Wife his Wife? And may he not do what he will with her? (Carries her off.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: He's at his old Tricks again.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Come, let's in, and endeavour to appease him, and then end our Mirth with a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: We attend your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, do me the favour to lead my Sister in.
Come, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Hold there, I will not part with you; I have two Hands, Madam, and can lead you both.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: FEar nothing; by what I could learn, by this time the old Lady is gone to her Chamber, or near being a▪bed.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Then we may have Time to talk more freely.

sp.speaker: Pbil.
sp.p: All is not so safe as you imagine. I fear another Storm before we yet can land. I know not by what means, but the Viscount is discover'd to be a Counterfeit, which I have all along suspected; but whether 'tis come to the Knowledge of my Aunt yet, I know not.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Therefore let's lose no time, but tye that Knot, which joins our Hearts and Hands for ever: That once over, we have no farther need of the Viscount.

div2.stage: Enter Lovemore, and the Viscount enrag'd, with Lights before 'em.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Never persuade me; I'll not stay to be fool'd at this rate any longer.—Go lead, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What's the Matter now?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Matter! Why there's Matter enough in hand. We are all undone; the Match is broke off again, and you are like to lose your Mistress. The Widow will not consent you shall marry her Niece; upon which, the Viscount enrag'd, (as indeed he has Cause) is resolv'd to stay no longer.
What 'twill come to, I know not.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: This is most unlucky. What's to be thought on next?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I left Prudence reasoning the Case with her; what will be the Conclusion, is most uncertain. Oh! here she comes.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! the saddest News!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why? What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: All the Business is over. Poor Mr. Cuningham—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ha! What of him? Speak.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: After a thousand Arguments, which I us'd to persuade her, she has at last resolv'd—I can't speak it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: On what? Prithee out with it.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Why, to marry the Viscount her self, and give you and your ten thousand Pounds to Mr. Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh the bless'd News! What say you now, Madam?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I'll swear I was in a Fright at first.
But art thou sure she'll hold in this Mind?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: For fear of the worst, get all things ready, and let it be done this Moment.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Here she comes. Seem concern'd to part with her, Sir, and try how she stands resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: And must I then lose her, Prudence!
Oh, the racking Thought! Hard! Hard! Decree of Fate! To part with all I hold most dear! I cannot bear it. (Walks about.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Cuningham, our Stars will have it so.

Tis hard indeed to part: But since there is no way left to save your Life, (which more than all the World I prize) but this only, I have at last resolv'd (tho' much against my Will) to give my self to the Viscount.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh! do not name it, Madam, the very Thought is worse, than Death.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'm sorry we are so near a kin, but that's not the chief Reason; your Vow to marry another, and yet when I consider she was false, and had to do with more, than one, and that the Child might as well not be yours, I think you were in the right to part: So I am content (since my Hopes are lost) that you shou'd marry with my Niece. But believe me, you do not know how much I'm troubled▪ to see another take what I so much desir'd. But we must endeavour to be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Never! Never! for since I lose you, farewel to Love and Joy: The rest of Life I'll waste in Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly! Damaris bad me tell you, that her Mistress stays for you at the Garden Door.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, very well. I'll go this Moment.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But what will you do to recal the Viscount, Madam, who left the House in Anger, nor told any one what his Designs were?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I heard him bid the Link-boy lead to the Devil Tavern. If you please, thither we'll go, and conclude upon the Matter. A Glass or two of Wine may fetch him about again.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Truly, Mr. Lovemore, I'm much oblig'd to you, and shall endeavour to return your friendly Advice. I hope we shall live as loving Neighbours ought, but now we lose time. The Viscount may perhaps be gone, should we stay longer.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll but give some Directions to my Man, and be there almost as soon as you.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: You will oblige us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: 'Tis main dark, nothing to be seen but the Sky and Stars. What can this Darkness portend! The Almanicks this Year say, That many things will be huddled in the dark.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why, thou art an Astrologer, Clodpole, thou talk'st so learnedly.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why, truly I am but a Piece of one; but had I been a great Schollard, I believe I shou'd have thought on things, that never had been thought on before.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Very likely, truly. But hark! What Noise is that? There's Brittle's House; may be she is coming out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Softly Damaris, just shut the Door, we'll not be far from it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Is your Husband fast, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I would not stir till I saw him asleep; he's snoring like one that's drunk.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That's her Voice. Madam, where are you?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: There they are, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: You find, Sir, I am as good as my Word. I hope you are a Man of Honour, as you say; yet were it to do again, I should hardly venture such another bold Attempt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Madam. Your Person and your Honour both are safe, whilst I am your Guard. Can none over hear us?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: All the Family, but Damaris and I, are gone to Bed; nor dare we be long from thence, lest my Husband should wake, and miss me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Talk not of parting e'er we well are met; that were unkind, Madam.
If you please, Madam, to walk a little farther this way, here's a Place more private, than the rest, and will best befit our Discourse.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'll not question your Honour any more, but trust my self with you; as you behave your self now, expect a greater Liberty another time.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll warrant you: This way, my Charmer.

div2.stage: (He leads her out; she takes hold of Damaris, who follows.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Damaris!

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'm here, Madam.
sp.stage: (Clodpole feels with his Stick for Damaris.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris!—Softly!—Damaris!—Damaris!

div2.stage: Enter Brittle, groping in the dark in a Cap and a Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Where can she be gone at this time of Night? I heard her steal down; I'll listen.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris, Where art thou, Damaris!—Odd, 'tis main dark.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Who have we here? Here's something more than ordinary. But I'll draw nearer.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris, Where art thou?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Here. (In a low Voice: Clodpole feels him with his Stick, thinks 'tis Damaris.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Oh! art thou there?

Well, Damaris, must not thee and I follow the Example of thy Mistress, and my Master? I'll warrant they'll be hugeous kind to one another; for my Master, you must know, has a mighty Love for her, and so belike she has for him; or else she wou'd ne'er a left her Husband a bed to a come to him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh horrid! 'tis so. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: How he snores now, if a Body were to hear him! Poor Cuckold! He little dreams what his Wife and my Master are doing. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh! this is my Country Chap again. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Poor Cuckold, 'tis good enough for him. For as they say, he uses her mighty ill. But, Damaris, must thee and I part thus? One little Bit to stay my Stomach, Damaris: 'Tis fit, we shou'd follow our Leaders. (Gues to Kiss.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I can hold no longer. Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Odd so! Oh! Oh! Who's that? Oh!

div2.stage: Puts his Stick a-cross, and in running out-stops against the Scenes; at last gets off.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: So—He's gone. Here's a Discovery at last! Here's a fine Virtuous Wife for you! But now all will out in spite of her. I'll send instantly for her Parents; they shall see now who's in the right. Oh bless us! What, make her Husband a Cuckold! Oh! Monstrous! (Goes to the Door, and calls.
Jeremy! the Varlet's a▪sleep, I'll warrant. Jeremy, I say.
(Jer. above) Do you call, Sir?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, I do call. Come down quickly, I must send you to my Father-in-law's.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: I come, Sir. (Puts a Rope out, and slides down.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Make haste, Sirrah. How long you are coming. Ah! Villain!
sp.stage: (Jeremy treads upon his Toes, and gets from him.
sp.p: You have trod upon my Corns, and lam'd me.
Come hither, and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: I dare not, Sir; you'll beat me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah! 'tis well I stand in need of thee.

Run to my Father and Mother-in-Law, and tell 'em, I intreat to speak with 'em this Moment; tell 'em I'll
never trouble 'em again as long as I live; beg 'em by all means to come.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Now they shall see what a Daughter they have.
Now I shall sure convince 'em of their Error!
But I hear some body coming!
May be I shall make a farther Discovery. (Stands aside.

div2.stage: Enter Lovemore, Mrs. Brittle, Damaris, and Clodpole.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I've stay'd long enough for one time: Should my Husband wake, and miss me, I were undone.
I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Stay one Minute longer, I beseech you, Madam.
I have not told you yet—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No more, Sir, if you love me. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, stay! How can you go, and leave me so soon?

You will have time enough to lie by that dull, stupid Clod, your Husband, e'er the Morning: Methinks I grudge him the least Look of you, since he knows not how to value so rich a Jewel. Let him live, and pore o'er his Bags, his Dross, and worldly Gains, whilst we know better how to waste our youthful Hours in softest Kisses, and everlasting Joys.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, blasting Sound! But I have heard enough.
Now to my Post. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Good Night, Sir: Now I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: When shall I be thus bless'd again?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: To Morrow I'll send for you; and, if possible, appoint another Meeting.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Till then, ten thousand Angels wait on thee. One Kiss e'er we part. (Kisses her. Oh, I could dwell for ever on thy Lips!
Sure, there's Enchantment on 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Farewel!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Adieu, my lovely Charmer. (Exit with Clod.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Now, Damaris, let's steal in: Softly! Softly!

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: O Lord, Madam! We are undone!
The Door is fast since we have been out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: What shall we do now, Damaris?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I wish my Master has not been down.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Let's call Jeremy softly.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Jeremy! Jeremy!

div2.stage: (They both call up to the Window in a soft Tone.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Jeremy! Jeremy! (In their Tone.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, my Master!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Lost! Undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah! Ha! my sweet Lady! Have I caught you at last!
Jeremy! Jeremy!
Where has your sweet Ladyship been, I pray, that you are so afraid of being discover'd? Come, I know you have a Lie in readiness: Let's have it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No where but just with Damaris, to take a little of the fresh Air; that's all, indeed, sweet Husband.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: To take the fresh Air, quotha!
Ah, I rather believe 'twas to take a Heat, you Witch you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Pray, Husband, let the Door be open'd?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No: You shall stay there till your Parents come.
I have sent for them: They shall see what Hours you keep. And know of your Gallant you just parted from, your vigorous Lover.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Madam, he over-heard all,
And we are undone. (Aside to her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: What, have you no Excuse ready?
No Invention? You and your wicked Instrument there, that stands like the Serpent at Eve's Elbow, to tempt her to Sin.
What, is your Prompter to Wickedness dumb?
I'd fain hear how you intend to excuse it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I don't go about to excuse it, Husband—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No; That's because you don't know how.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I do confess, I have been to meet a Gentleman, but not alone; Damaris was with me. And sure there was no Crime in a little harmless Chat.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, not in the least; making me a Cuckold is no harm at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Pray, Husband, let me in, and I'll never do the like again, as long as I live; but you shall hence-forward find me the most dutiful Wife, that you could wish for. Pray, Husband, trust me but this once.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Do not disgrace me to my Parents, by exposing me at this unseasonable Hour, in which I do confess I am much to blame—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh! Do you so?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: But forgive me now, I'll never do it again.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hang them that believes you, I say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I am sure I never injur'd you in all my Life; but am as innocent as the Child unborn, from doing the Ill, which you suspect.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: It may be so: 'Twas not your Fault then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Pray, dear Husband, believe me, and let me in.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: On my Knees I ask your Pardon, do but open the Door.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: If you let me in this time, 'twill work upon me more, than all the Liberty in the World cou'd do beside.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I care not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Indeed, Husband, I love you dearly, and love you only: How can you then be so cruel to refuse me?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah, cunning Crocodile?
Now you are caught, 'tis dear Husband, sweet Husband, 'tis only you I love: But at another time, 'tis good for nothing old Fool. No, no, I know you well enough, and so shall your Parents now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Pray, Husband, let the Door be open'd▪

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Try me but this once.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I tell you, no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Not once more?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: If you provoke me, I may despair, grow desperate, and do a Deed, which you may repent.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good lack! What will your sweet Ladyship do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I'll kill my self with this Knife here.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, very well!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Nay, 'twill not be so well as you imagine neither. Every body knows how ill we have liv'd, and when I'm dead, People will think you murder'd me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Therefore I'll kill my self, to have my Death reveng'd upon you.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Odd, I'll trust to that.
Besides, killing ones self has been a great while out of fashion. But why don't you dispatch? Methinks you are long about it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt,
sp.p: You may believe me, for I'll certainly do it, if you persist.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Odd, I'll venture it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Besides, when I am dead, my Ghost shall haunt you.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah, if I cou'd but once get rid of your Person here, I should not fear your Ghost hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Have you no Pity left?
I am just going to do it.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: And yet you are long about it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Since nothing but my Death can satisfy you—
There and there!

div2.stage: (Pretends to stab her self with her Fan, and salls.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Oh, she has don't! She has don't!
Oh cruel, barbarous Monster, to make her kill her self!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Now, Damaris, you find too late I did not jest—
I know thou'lt see my Death reveng'd upon my cruel Husband, who has accus'd me falsly; for I affirm with my dying Breath, I never wrong'd him. Farewel!
Death beckons me into a dark and gloomy Vale, where I must follow.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: She's gone! She's gone!
Oh, thou worse than Savage! To murder so sweet a Lady, so innocent and so good: Nay, I'll swear you did it. (Cries over her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I hear no Noise! (Looks frighten'd. Is't possible the Devil shou'd be so great with her, that she cou'd kill her self to be reveng'd on me!
But I'll light a Candle, and go see.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Now, Damaris, stand close in this Corner:
Close, Close. (They stand aside.

div2.stage: Enter Brittle with a Light; they slip by him, go in, and lock the Door: He looks about.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I thought indeed how well she'd do it: Here's none of her! She made me believe she kill'd her self, and the mean while ran away. Well, e'en let her go; I shall have this Satisfaction, her Parents shall be Witness of her Hours. I'll in, and wait their coming.

div2.stage: (Goes to the Door, and finds it lock'd. Knocks.
Mrs. Brittle and Damaris above at the Window, where he was.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Away, you idle Sot; is this a time of Night for an honest Man to come home in?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Go, go, you may be asham'd!

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, have you the Impudence—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: How many Nights am I forc'd to sit up to wait for his coming in? And he tells the World, 'tis I am to blame. But now it shall be seen who's to blame, and who not. My Father and Mother are coming, they shall see what Hours you keep—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I confess, I stand amaz'd at this Impudence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: They shall know all.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, have you the Face to deny—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Go, go, I'll hear none of your impudent Excuses; you are drunk, you Sot, you Swine. But here comes my honourable Father and Mother.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Peter and Lady Pride.
sp.p: I'm glad you are come to be Witness of what I still suffer, by this ungrateful Usage of a cruel Husband. You see what Hours he keeps; every Night at the Tavern roaring with his Companions, whilst I am forc'd to sit at home alone, waiting for his coming; and when he does come, he strait raves and abuses me at such a rate, that I am not able to endure it.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, was there ever such Impudence!
I wish this Candle were in my Belly, if—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I know what he'll say now, if you'll believe him; he'll tell you, that I am still in the wrong, and 'tis I that have been out at this late Hour, and as for his part, he has been within all this Evening, and knows nothing of all this Matter, not he: But I'll leave your selves to judge, if this is an Hour for an honest Husband to come home at.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why then may I never—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: You see he's so drunk, he can hardly stand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Faugh!—I smell him hither.
He stinks of Liquors and Tobacco like a Tarpaulin, that has not been sober whilst his Twelve-Months Pay wou'd last.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I tell you, that I am not drunk, nor have I been out of my House.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Stand farther off, I cannot bear the Scent of a Drunkard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I told you he wou'd deny it.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I say, that 'tis she that has been out just now, and with her Gallant, and therefore I sent for you; and that I have not been out of my Doors.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Do you hear him? But Damaris can justify, I have not set my Foot over the Threshold since Day-light.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: If she has, never believe me more.
I can assure your Honours 'tis true; for I have not been out of her Company since he went out to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Therefore I do beseech you, good Father and Mother, to revenge my Cause, for I am not able to endure it any longer: If I do, you'll never see me alive another Week.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange thing, that she must be believed, and I not.
I tell you—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Stand farther off.
Faugh! What a Smell there's about him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well then; I'll stand farther off, if you will but hear me speak. (Goes backward. I shall say nothing but the Truth, and what I can prove.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Again at your Proofs, and your idle Jealousies!

Be dumb, Coxcomb; it were a good deed to break your Head, for sending thus for us out of our Beds, and making Fools of us still. If you ever dare to do the like again, we'll find a Means to handle you—
If there be no Law (but cutting of Throats) to revenge these Affronts—I say no more—But remember you are warn'd.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: If you wou'd but let me tell why I sent for you—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: We have heard and seen too much already.
Therefore dare not to speak a Word more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: And is this all his Punishment?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: No; Come down, and he shall ask your Pardon. 'Tis the least he can do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: 'Twill be to no purpose; when your Backs are turn'd, he'll be as bad again.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I say no more Disputes, but do as I command. (They come down from the Window.
Now, Son-in-law, kneel down, and ask your Wife Forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Shall I forgive him; no, I desire to be divorc'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, Daughter, I say you must pardon him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I'll endeavour to obey you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Why don't you kneel, and do as I command?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, I find there's no Remedy, she has over-reach'd me again, and I must submit: But I am resolv'd I'll get rid of this Nooze, tho' I tuck my self up in another.
sp.stage: (Sir Peter makes him kneel to his Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Come, say after me. Madam, I ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Madam, I ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: For the Folly I have committed—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: For the Folly I have committed in marrying you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: In my wild Suspicions.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: In my wild Suspicions.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Which I do declare were utterly false.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Which I do declare were utterly false.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: And that I swear never to do the like again.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: And that I swear never to do the like again, if I were once unmarried.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Here—Kiss the Book. (Gives her Hand. But if ever you do't again—
You see 'tis to no purpose to turn Hagard; if you do, I'll tame you. (Aside to him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Look if the Noise has not brought all the Company hither.

div2.stage: Enter Viscount, Widow, Lovemore, Cuningam, Philadelphia, Prudence, Clodpole, and Jeffrey, with Lights before 'em.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir Peter. Sir, I hope you will not take it ill; we saw a Light in your House, and so made bold: We are resolv'd to spend an Hour or two in Mirth, and hope you will all join with us.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Your Ladyship I know will pardon it upon this Occasion. (To Lady Pride.

sp.speaker: Lady Pride.
sp.p: Is your Ladyship marry'd? May we give you Joy?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: My Niece and Mr. Cuningham are.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Give you Joy then.

sp.speaker: Cun. and Phil.
sp.p: We thank you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now, Sir, since our Hands are join'd, and all is reconcil'd, I have a Boon to ask.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Whate'er it be, conclude it done.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I have observ'd some Sparks of Love between Jeffrey and Prudence; and I believe they wou'd be glad to follow our Example.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What say'st thou, Jeffrey? If thou hast a Mind to marry, speak freely.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Sir, I have debated much about the Matter, and am at last resolv'd to venture.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Then if you, Madam, give your Consent, and Prudence be willing, we'll put 'em together.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: With all my Heart; Prudence has been always a good Servant, I'll say that for her.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: There's my Hand then; the rest of my Body shall be forth coming.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A Match.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Then let me speak. Clodpole loves Damaris, and I believe wou'd be glad to make up the Chorus; now if Mrs. Brittle please to part with her—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: You shall have my Consent with all my Heart; and I'll give a Sum of Money to be rid of her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And I'll give Clodpole something to set him up in a little Farm in the Country.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris!—Dost hear that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: What say you, Damaris?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: If I thought he'd make a good Husband, and not be jealous—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That I dare answer for him.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Well, then 'tis agreed, and there's my Hand.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: For better for worse.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: To have and to hold; a Tenement for Life.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: And now all things being thus happily concluded—

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: No, Mr. Cuningham, not while your Friend is unprovided. Methinks 'twere pity he shou'd be no Actor in this Comedy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, my Thoughts are not yet fix'd so much upon any Object, but the next I encounter can retrieve the past.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: My Friend never wants a Mistress (I'll say that for him) in any Place, if he has but an Opportunity, which he seldom wants. I have often wonder'd at his Luck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Say you so? I find he makes it his Business to ensnare and deceive Women at this rate.

I'm glad I know it in time, whilst I have Power to make my Retreat. I had like to have been finely caught. Well, Husband, seeing so many join'd in Happiness, if you'll promise never to be jealous, I'll promise from this Moment never to give you Cause, and endeavour to make you as happy as I can.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Wou'd you'd give me Cause once to believe you.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: Well then, if you are all agreed, the Parson that marry'd Mr. Cuningham is but just by; e'en send for him, and let him end the Work he has begun.
For my part, I intend to put off mine for some time longer.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: How! My Lord! Have you serv'd me thus? Did I forsake all for you, and do you pretend to—

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: No Words now, 'twill spoil Company; another time we'll discourse it farther. Come, let's have a Dance, and then to Bed.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: With all our Hearts.

sp.speaker: Visc.
sp.p: 'Tis well: So now, you that are ready to taste the Sweets of Matrimony, fall to; for my part, I have no great Stomach to it yet.
sp.l: And none I hope will blame me if I tarry,
Since those that wed in haste, as fast miscarry.
